Now the story may seem like another slice of life, but trust me, it's far from it.  It's about as far away from being a generic slice of life as a black kid away from his runaway biological father.  The show is not afraid to take simple ideas and completely morph them into something new.  I honestly can not compare this show to any other show I have ever seen in my life.  The show is highly original giving off the vibe that a lot of hard work and effort was put into the story to make it work carefully and steadily like making a cake just right so that an angry bridezilla won't cut you up with her dagger.


This anime brings on some pretty heavy themes and displayed some of the harsh but very true aspects of life.  Themes from depression to being sex deprived like a Japanese Weeaboo without his tentacle hentai are all a part of what makes Tatami Galaxy an immersive experience that pulls the audience in with it's dark themes.  This is surprising because most of the time, people aren't pulled into anime with dark themes, instead they want to be pulled into a world that can allow themselves to escape from real life.  

However, as I just mentioned, the Tatami Galaxy, though being the opposite of using unrealistic themes to immerse an audience, manages to suck people up and honestly I felt like I was immersed more than an IGN reviewer being immersed in a COD Game.


The anime brings on crazy events from left field that will make the most sane of minds go insane trying to figure out what the hell is going on onscreen.  This is thanks to some beautiful symbolism which keeps the audience thinking of what special meaning a certain part of the story has.  This is thanks to the amazing script writing and as I'll discuss later, the art!


The series is highly episodic but that never hurts the series in any way, sure there is at least 1 episode that doesn't really further the plot in any way but other than that each episode has a series of convoluted events that in the end wraps up together so that everything that has happened in the anime matters and that no minutes were wasted on pointless crap in this anime.  I can't say the same thing for Zankyou no Terror, which in my opinion had some insanely pointless episodes and not to mention characters *SHOTS FIRED* but all and all the series of events portrayed in this anime are all really interesting and should keep you glued to your chair.  More glued than Ryuuji's semen on Taiga's fa-err been reading too many doujinshis


I talked about choice many times in the synopsis and how it plays a big role in this story, well without spoiling much let's just say that at the end of every episode the clock rewinds and we find ourselves at square one again only to find out our main protagonist has made a different decision than the previous one.  This could throw some viewers off like Melissa McCarthy upside down off a Roller Coaster but once you realize what's going on it all becomes clear and in the end you'll seem more idiotic than the person who 

reviewed Pokemon Alpha Sapphire.  TOO MUCH WATER, THE FUCKKK! But the choices makes the series all the more special, and the way they are handled makes the experience even more rich and engaging.


How did it present its genres you ask?  Well then, as a mystery it always kept me wondering why the sequence of events are happening and what are the motives behind each of the characters and how they act.  So as a mystery it does better than Freddy the Fish so thank god.  As a lover of puzzles, this anime is a dream come true, always having me thinking, and thinking about how the events all tie together, and that's what makes the Tatami Galaxy a great interactive mystery show!  As a romance, it may not seem like it at first but the hints of romance here and there and well everywhere adds flavor to Tatami Galaxy.  Our main protagonist is constantly reminded that the opportunity for romance is right in front of him, but instead becomes a hopeless romantic that is dying to be loved.  Romance fuels mostly all of the characters motivations which makes it such an important theme int he story.  Last but not least, the psychological element of the show was nothing short of immersive and breathtaking.  We take a great look into seeing what the heck is going on inside of the protagonist's mind and how his thoughts and actions manifest inside his head to ultimately make his decisions.  This is further amplified later in the show when I talk about the art/animation.  My favorite episodes were the ones where we got to explore the psychological 

nature of the show as well as the romantic themes of the show as well.


The only problem I had with this show is the pacing, not the pacing of the show but the pacing of the dialogue.  The dialogue moves faster than production of Loli Body Pillows, do I want said pillow? No, I'm not Elmo okay?  Honestly at first it was the biggest turnoff for me, but if you can keep up with the inner monologues then you're all set.  I managed to be able to keep up with the pace, but slow readers be aware that if you watch this you might miss the full experience.  


Also, a small little gripe I had was the ending.  The ending was a solid ending but I can't help to feel like there was missing something.  I felt that in some ways it was abrupt and that there should have been more but all and all they pulled off a good ending!



THE CHARACTERS

Lets start off with Watashi, our main protagonist who is the hopeless romantic.  Over the course of the series we get to learn more about him and the dilemmas always gets in.  His viewpoints on life are indeed both hilarious and to some extent actually true on the reality of life.  Throughout the story, he gets fully fleshed out as we see different angles of who he truly is based off of the circles he joins in each episode.  As time rewinds and he joins a new club we get to see more of his personality and who he truly is.  What's great about him is that he's not the best with women unlike every harem protagonist out there, nor is the stereotypical small steroid balled Arnold Schwarzennegar type of guy.  Watashi is not any not any of those, he's his own character and doesn't stick to an archetype.  This allows for a more realistic type of personality for Watashi which in turn makes him 

more relatable and not just a cut and paste slap on character.  Though easily manipulated Watashi as a main character is both interesting and fun to watch, which makes him the rose of the everlasting spectacle garden of flowers that is The Tatami Galaxy.


Ozu can be percieved as the main "anatagonist" of this story.  Sure he looks uglier a Samuel Jackson Rebel Wilson baby crack baby, but that doesnt mean that his character is actually bad.  He has hidden motives throughout the story that we as the audience figure out bit by bit, piece by piece, tit by tit along the way.  He like to cause unhappiness among people, like a clown with anal beads showing little kids at a party how to make them disappear.  Anyways he is a very intriguing character, though dark on the outside he has some hidden stuff going on on the inside that may make him seem brighter than a stripper's glow in the dark tassles. Him and Watashi both get the most screen time and are both characters that are extremely 3 dimensional and for that I have to give props.


Akashi is more cold than the ice cream on Pico's nipples but don't let that fool you!  She is cold to mostly everyone but Watashi making her character highly interesting.  I wish she had more screentime because I felt that she wasnt as fleshed out as she should have. But what is indeed great about her though is that we get to see both sides of the same coin with her cold side for everyone but Watashi, and her more outgoing side whenever she talks with Watashi.  As the love interest of this story she does things anime girls 

nowadays dont do, that is, being as annoying as Obama Care and hornier than your elementary school librarian.  She's afraid of moths, and I don't blame her, they're more terrifying than Kriten Stewart's honey pot, but it's the tiny quirks like this that allow her character to be fun whenever on screen.  


Other characters include


The self proclaimed deity, Seitarou Higuchi

The doll lover Masaki Jougasaki who is a part of the cinema circle

And one of my personal favorites Johnny, who is a cowboy that is supposed to represent Watashi's hormones.  Seriously, whoever thought of Johnny has to be a genius

All and all, the cast is full of interesting and intriguing characters that are fun and enjoyable to watch.  The mystery behind the characters allows you to focus on the screen for the whole 20 minutes without taking bathroom breaks, or clicking on pornhub pop ups.  Though the only flaws are that some of the side characters aren't as fleshed out as people would like them to be.



ART/ANIMATION

Now lets get into the art and animation.  Some might dismiss this art as being childish and uninspired showing a lack of effort.  Well, to those people I have to say look again because there is much more to it!  The elements of design and composition all appear here is masterful ways.  Colors contrast, they unify, they have rhythm and can repeat.  The whole show almost appears to dance from style to style in a snap and that is the beauty and nature of the show.  The abstractness of the art also allows for some stellar

psychedelic imagery that is not only exciting to look at but also it also livens up the world of Tatami Galaxy. For you see, the world is not made to be pretty all the time and that is what this art shows perfectly.  They also use actual real life background images too in some places which is weird yet shows off how innovative the art truly is. The character designs are simple yet they perfectly blend in perfectly with the versatile art style.  Although I understand the style they chose for this show I just wish things would be more detailed during the scenes where nothing psychological or major is happening but that's the biggest issue with the art a lack of background detail.  Other than that it's amazing.  Thankfully the animation of the show is highly fluent with the rarest of rare occasions being choppy to the point where you'd have to have eyes like a hawk.  The character movements feel genuine and the special effects of the show are beautifully presented.  From

fireworks exploding to great directed psychological scenes, this anime utilizes every aspect of it's art style and uses it to its advantage.  Honestly, the art and animation of this show though abstract and out of the norm offers up some jaw dropping visuals and has to be one of my personal favorite art styles I've seen in any anime.



THE SOUND

The sound of the Tatami Galaxy is probably the weakest part for me but that's not saying much seeing how it's still very good.  The voice acting for Watashi is excellently done by Asanuma Shintaro, and might I add for a voice actor to speak faster than superman thrusting into Lois Lane, without stumbling over his words, it's a job well done. I've always wondered how much power Superman had though, would Lois Lane just like, I don't know, one thrust and she flys through the wall.  Anyways, all the voice actors fit, Ozu's voice was great and it brought more life to his schemish nature.  The ost was solid, not the most memorable in my opinion but still stands above most Osts I've seen.  The songs were utilized really well and the quality of the music fit the tone of the story.  The opening grew on me as well as the ending and I felt as if there was really no problem with the sound.  It fit the story and the characters like a XXL condom on a Terry Crews.


So adding all my scores together


Giving the story a 9.3

The characters a 9.4

The Art/Animation a 9

and the sound a 8.5


The Tatami Galaxy gets a score of 8.99 out of FUCK IT, a 9/10 giving it a recommendation of better than sex.


Seriously ladies and gentlemen, if you are now having sexual intercourse with your lover, spouse, or even best friend to get back at your other best friend, please, drop your pixie stick, sit down on your computer, cover up your cock a doodle doo, or if you are female, just put on panties and watch this show.  Literally, I love this show at the moment and it is a fantastic piece of literature with great narrative and characters that feel like they are about to pop right out of the page.

I don't know where to start.  I don't want to be too harsh about this because I've only watched two episodes, but so far I think it's entertaining.  I'll be as nice as I can in this review.
Story
I find the story intriguing, but I'm disappointed by its episodic nature.  It's like there's no point to what I'm watching because it'll just be irrelevant in the next episode.  I hope there's something that ties this all together and it's not just pointless.  I would've liked things to be longer.  I'm not saying Tatami should be one of those overly longanimes with lots of fillers, but it's hard to thoroughly examine 4 years in one episode.  I would've liked it to be a bit longer.  That's just me.  I like analyzing things.  I'm afraid that if it just rewinds back at the end of each episode the show will become boring, and repetitive.  And how's the character development going to play out here if we're just watching them repeat things in a different universe?  Maybe they should've showed the universes from different points of views so that you'd get to know the characters more, and to avoid repetitive things.  If each episode ends the same way, Watashi-san refuses to find love, and it's that way for the entire series, I can't say that I'll be impressed by this.  I find the concept interesting, how it's playing out so far can be better, and I'm worried about how this is going to turn out.  I may be speaking too soon so I won't take any points off for that.  

7/10


Art

Personally, I love the artwork.  It's very distinct, and appealing.  The backgrounds are done very beautifully, and the characters are drawn nicely.  As far as character design goes they are just very appealing.  Nothing amazing, but they're very nice.  And gasp!  You can actually tell some of the characters apart.  I love how they gave some of the characters very distinct features.  However, I am not fond of Watashi-san's character design.  Plus it reminded me too much of Mr.Despair's.  I also want to note the clothing because I can tell the art directors put some thought into them.  Unlike in most animes where they're just outlandish.  I liked their use of patterns, tones, textures, shades, and sometimes the usage of actual pictures/videos.  That makes the artwork edgy, and unique.  However, the animation was a mess.  The animations were choppy, and lazy more than half the time.  Sometimes the animations got ridiculously choppy, and it seemed to be more of amateur work.  Although I can tell they put lots of effort into the artwork it just doesn't make up for the terrible animation.  Not to mention they reused a lot of animations.  That just makes the show more boring.  Don't get me wrong.  The animation wasn't extremely choppy...most of the time, but it's choppy just enough for you to notice it.  It makes me wonder.  Did they not shade, used a lot of textures, and used real stuff etc for artistic purposes or because of budget money?  Maybe just pure laziness.  That just bugs me, and takes a bit away from the niceness of the artwork.  

6/10 


Sound

I like the sound.  I think the soundtrack is quirky, especially the ED.  I like the OP, but it doesn't really stand out to me.  The bgm is decent, but I'm not really listening to it.  It's not noticeable, or remarkable.  I love the ED, I like the OP.  Overall, Idk it's alright.

5/10


Character

I think all of the characters are unique, and I really enjoy them.  Although they're very vague, and I'd like to get to know them more.  So far Watashi-san seems a bit of a blah main, but just a little bit.  I don't know how I'm going to if I just watch them repeat shit, but maybe there's some sort of twist end I'm not aware of.  I'll say it again.  I'm very very worried about character development right now because of its episodic nature.  It'll go back and time, and all that they've learned will be worth nothing in the next episode.  +points for the characters being realistic for once in an anime.

7.5/10


Enjoyment

The overall enjoyment of the show is fairly high for me.  None of it is laugh out loud for me or anything, but it's just amusing.  The weirdness of the situation, and the oddness of the characters.  How they present it to you is great, but it could play out better.  This kind of thing is very hard to find in anime.  Like I said, I'm very worried about this getting old, and me getting bored of it a couple episodes from now.  And let's not forget Watashi-san's fast talking.  Right now it's kind of annoying to me, and I hope they stop doing it in later episodes. 

8/10


Overall 

This anime is lots of fun, and its strange nature is amusing.  Although essential, and technical aspects take away from it.  I feel like it's just a show too focused on details rather than the big picture.  In the end there better be a point to all of this.

6.5-7(?)/10

For the sake of clarification, I will preface with something that reads more like a conclusion: Yojouhan Shinwa Taikei (which I will from here on refer to as The Tatami Galaxy) is a solid and endearing romance anime - the art and comedic light-hearted tone of events makes the characters feel likeable and compelling each in their own way, and The Tatami Galaxy does certainly have a lot of what the "enlightened" crowd like to parade as artistic merit, in the way that it tells its story, and in the way the orchestral soundtrack coincides nicely with what is going on on screen. If youare looking for a light-hearted romance anime with a unique premise/artstyle, or are someone who can greatly enjoy "artsy" stuff just for being "artsy", The Tatami Galaxy is right up your alley. Additionally the OP and ED are very nice, and it does a nice twist with them towards the end.


It is true that The Tatami Galaxy is good, and it is true that it is "different", but in the modern world, where lots of different and unique media can easily be found by straying off the beaten path even slightly, something is not made into a masterpiece just because it's different. The matter of fact is that The Tatami Galaxy, when looked at through a cynical lens, can be very formulaic and repetitive, with some flaws that stick out like a sore thumb.


The first of these is funnily enough, the artstyle. Although the artstyle does indeed bring its charm to the show's presentation, and is a big part of The Tatami Galaxy's aforementioned artistic merit, it feels rather inconsistent in quality. There are times where the "traditional art" aesthetic brings beauty to scenes, but there are other times where it can appear amateurish, such as a loss of facial detail at medium-distance shots, where there really shouldn't be such a decline in detail. Overall the art is enticing, but largely only because it's "different". As someone who has watched quite a few shows with unique artstyles, the visual presentation of The Tatami Galaxy does not feel like anything special (this however does not extend to the soundtrack, which has some standout tracks. Many people will love the soundtrack, even though it was not the kinda thing that wows me personally).


Secondly, the character cast are endearing because of their exaggerated personalities and often-comical designs and animations, but the characters don't really have any traits of note aside from these personalities and animations, which results in making the cast feel a bit two-dimensional. The MC is an outcast shut in, Akashi is the cold-but-sweet love interest, Ozu is mischeivous, Higuchi is a comedic relief, Hanuki is a playful girl who likes to get drunk, Jougasaki is a pervert, and any other characters are not shown often enough to have much of note. Hell, one of the supporting characters, Aijima is not even shown until episode 9, which makes it hard to care about him in any way. Aside from the main character developing in the last two episodes as a result of spoilerific circumstances, there is almost no character development present in The Tatami Galaxy.


Additionally, although you could say that it comes with the "alternate timelines" premise, The Tatami Galaxy feels formulaic, especially in the first 5 episodes. The formula goes as such: MC joins an extracurricular club (or doesn't) at the start of college, they don't fit in, meet the weird and devious Ozu and then comedic things happen until the MC misses his opportunity to woo Akashi and feels like his two college years are wasted. Although this sounds like the kind of thing that is "the point" of the show, it still feels like this aspect could have been delivered a lot better, at least in the first half. In the final few episodes, we start to see events which transpired in earlier timelines from a different perspective, which is cool and allows the viewer to better appreciate what happened, but in the first half, the show resorts to recycling dialogue and scenes, which gives the impression that The Tatami Galaxy has little confidence in its audience. Characters are reintroduced and treated as though they are new each episode, which limits how much development the characters experience and perspectives from which we can see them.


This execution of the premise also gives the first half of The Tatami Galaxy very little stakes or reasons for the viewer to care about it, because at the end of the first episode the MC will timewarp back to the start of the formula no matter what happens. It is for these reasons that I thought the first half of The Tatami Galaxy was flat-out unenjoyable, however the second half picked things up greatly as the writing started to have confidence in the audience, and the ending was heartwarming and left things off at just the right note for a light-hearted romance anime.


Overall, The Tatami Galaxy is an artistic anime that often reaches amazing heights of quality, but is limited in its scope by a lack of willingness to flesh out the character cast beyond their two-dimensional traits for the majority of the show. It is certainly a show that was bold enough to do something unique and as a result will remain a cult classic for years to come, but only with a higher budget for more consistently-good art and more time to consider the writing could it have become truly worthy of the label "masterpiece".

When I decided to watch this show at a friends request I had no idea what I was in for. The only knowledge that I gathered from my compatriot was that he held the show in high regard. Upon completing this Anime I can see where his love for it comes from. 
Story: 9
Impressive almost doesn't do it justice. The creators of this show took an ordinary idea and turned it into an extraordinary one. Most of the story is told in a very episodic fashion, which normally would be taken as each episode having generally nothing to do with the next, but it isquite the opposite. Each episode is crafted with detail and woven together in such a way to make several layers of what seems like different tales into one over arching story. The last two episodes serve too tie everything together and were the best in the entire show. If anything was weak about this show, it isn't this. 


Art: 7


A very interesting animation style lead to my eyes being very pleased, and the change from the norm was very welcomed. So why only a seven some might ask. Clearly from what I just said it's not like I found the style of the show jarring or unpleasant. The animation was just good, nothing really wrong with it, but nothing that stood out and screamed masterful. If anything this was the weakest part of the show. 


Sound: 8


Now besides the immensely wonderful opening and ending songs, nothing else in the music department really nailed it for me. It worked for the show don't get me wrong, but nothing made me pause an episode to look up the OST to download it. Where the music falters, the voice acting shines even brighter. Each character sounded fitting and the voice actors/actresses in question delivered wonderful performances. One of my favorites being the devilish voice of Ozu. I love this beautiful bastard and his voice added to this love. 


Character: 9


Speaking of Ozu, the characters of this show are beautiful. Each one brought a brilliance to each scene they were in with ease. Watashi, Ozu, Akashi, and everyone else in the cast went above and beyond on the fun meter. I honestly haven't seen an ensemble of characters that I've liked this much since "Baccano!", and that alone is a testament to how wonderful these people are. Now let me get down to the winner of the cast. ***Spoiler*** Ozu not only field my heart with joy and laughter every time he appeared on screen but in the end when you figure out that he was actually the best of bros the entire time was just wonderful.***End*** So as characters go, you have quite a group that will make each episode worth tuning in for. 


Enjoyment: 10


Enjoyment is something that is completely subjective. Although I don't believe in giving any show a ten because something can't be truly perfect, when it comes to my enjoyment however its a different story. I couldn't have loved this show anymore. I would recommend it to anyone flat out. It is worth your time, even if you end up not enjoying it as much as I. 


Overall: 8.6


In conclusion: The Tatami Galaxy was a show rich in characters and had a very standard story told in a very unique way. With an interesting art style and wonderful voice acting this show excels at almost everything across the board. Lowest point for the show would be in its animation, although no where near bad, I felt like it didn't quite have anything that made me go wow. This is a must watch for people who are looking for something different. If you aren't then watch it anyways. It was one hell of a fun ride, and I thank my friend for the recommendation. Thanks for reading

what a fucking masterpiece. 
bolstered by its utterly unique hyperstylized artstyle, tatami galaxy is a visceral and heartwrenching thinkpiece that, despite its zany and whimsical overtones and eye-melting rapidfire technicolor imagery, is GROUNDED in reality. 
in fact, all of that boisterous linework, rapid editing that would make anno jealous, a grandiose and whimsical score that harkens back to ghibli and even disney, and art decisions that morph into pure surrealism at points merely EMPHASIZES the heavy and real questions of this series; as someone who is in his third year of college, chasing after my own rosy-colored fantasy that i have simultaneously given up oncompletely, i felt like this show understood me like no other show ever has. 


of course, the perfection of this show goes beyond the flawless stylized art; on top of being a cathartic look into the soul-mucking reality of what it's like to be an aimless, thirsty/girl-hungry college student, the show is a goddamn great time travel story. 


the groundhog day premise of looping back into alternate timelines surprisingly never got old, and the writing (infamous for having machine-gun fire dialogue that flashes by with five or so paragraphs a goddamn minute) just keeps everything unexpected and fresh no matter how many days are looped, and how many timelines are explored. 


tatami galaxy will reach out and grab you by the neck and hurl you through its 11 episodes faster than its main character can spit out words at you. it's an auteuristic masterwork, a testament to the unique vision of masaaki yuasa, an anime that stands heads and shoulders above the rest when it comes to dealing with real life issues of love, self-doubt, and the search for meaning during the turbelent fickleness of youth. 


this is a perfect show, and if you're like me, someone who's drifting through college wondering where the hell it all went wrong, then it will be the perfect show for you.

I don't think any other anime had the same instantaneous impact on me as Yojouhan Shinwa Taikei did upon finishing the final episode. I also can't recall any other anime becoming one of my favourites so quickly. 
One of my absolute favourite aspects of the show is how the show is how the plot slowly unravels over the course of the show. One might say that this should be a basic storytelling requirement, but rarely is a piece of art able to accomplish this with the perfect pacing that Tatami Galaxy has. The way in which uses the plot device as a means of world-buildingis masterful; small, seemingly insignificant details pop-up in multiple timelines, and often transform into much bigger, considerably less insignificant details, which allows the world and the characters within it feel genuinely real. I found myself becoming more attached to these people than in any anime I've ever watched, aside from perhaps Hunter x Hunter, and the experience of realising this during the last episode made me tear up slightly.


However, what's most interesting about this is how the creators were able to meticulously piece together this puzzle before the viewers eyes over the course of 11 episodes, while simultaneously moving the story along at breakneck speed. One possible flaw would be that reading the subtitles while taking in the events on screen is incredibly difficult, although I will say that my speed-reading skills improved significantly by the end.

But this wasn't done without reason, as it accurately conveys the mentality of the protagonist, who drastically overthinks every decision he has to make; a flaw I assume most people can relate to (as the writers most likely realise). 


This anime's greatest achievement, though, would be the insane visuals. Never before have I seen a piece of animation with the level of visual storytelling of Tatami Galaxy. Most of the animation is used to represent the inner workings of the protagonists mind - visual metaphors are in abundance here. I don't think this show would be anywhere near as good without the the level of detail and love put into every second of the animation. I believe that for something to have god-tier animation, I should be able to understand the ideas and concepts without the sound turned on, and the show goes above and beyond this requirement. I'm sure I would be able to understand the ideas, concepts, plot and characters arcs with no sound or subtitles to guide me, simply through the genius-level direction of  Masaaki Yuata. 


As you can see, I have refrained from stating any of the aformentioned ideas and concepts, simply because (as someone who myself went in completely blind) I would say that part of my enjoyment of the series was discovering all of it myself as the show went on, and watching the mural unfold before my eyes without any knowledge of where it would go or which direction it would take. Never has a piece of art taught me so much about myself and many of the toxic mentality's that have held me back from enjoying the simpler joys of life, and given me the motivation to go out and do exactly that. Without a doubt, The Tatami Galaxy earns its place as one of the greatest anime of all time, and one of my own personal favourites ever.


10/10.

This will be my review to the anime 'Yojouhan Shinwa Taikei', also more well-known as 'The Tatami Galaxy'. From this point on I will refer to this anime as Tatami Galaxy. Tatami Galaxy is done by the studio MADHOUSE, a studio most if not all anime watchers know about. MADHOUSE has been one of the old and big anime studios from the past. Even though they still exist their might has long since been gone. Tatami Galaxy though is part of their golden age when MADHOUSE made one timeless classic after another, this being one of them. Tatami Galaxy is written by Masaaki Yuasa, oneof anime industries biggest geniuses, and I am not exaggerating in the slightest. Tatami Galaxy has long since been established as a anime high elitist anime. By that I mean an anime that's been associated as a high-grade masterpiece. Now that I've rambled enough, let's get to this.



Plot/Story: Without spoiling anything of the plot twists or anything similar; the story revolves around Watashi, a young man who just entered the high-school life. Shortly, he is during one visit at a local ramen stall being accompanied by a strange man who tells him he will bind either Watashi or Ozu to Atashi as a love partner with the thread of love. Atashi is a pretty girl with black hair who Watashi has fallen for. Ozu, on the other side is a fellow he met and befriended during his high-school life.

Each episode shows Watashi taking another route in his life, choosing a different club he joins during that time.


While the story isn't as grand as it seems, it gets better. Trust me. And that's actually all I can say without spoiling too much. The core of this anime lies in the characters anyway.


Art: Just outstanding. It is not any downright expensively detailed anime, it is the art of the anime that is typical for Yuasa that gives this anime the high art quality it deserves. The opening and ending are also both very stylish and fit the anime well.


Sound: Apart from the heavily SFX-based sound both the opening and ending song are great. They reflect the nature of the anime. I have nothing to say against it.


Characters: Yes, the characters. The heart of this show. As well as the message this anime delivers through the main character Watashi. Easily influenced and easy to forget important things or to not see things as clearly as they are. Ozu, a fiendish man who lives to make other people's lives miserable. Often described as a man-yokai. Akashi, an ambitious young woman who does what she does best. Working seriously. She's like the type of girl who once she gets into something she is determined to do it with her all. Even if it's a bit stupendous. There are of course a few more characters in this but describing them as well is 1. too much for this review and 2. takes away from experiencing them yourself. This is supposed to be just a small appetizer to start watching the show. So go watch it! 


Enjoyment & verdict: Yes, of course I enioyed it. I gave it a high 9/10. Some people might lynch be for not giving it a round 10 but that's just how it is. Deal with it. I also do recommend it but only to veterans in the anime fandom. This might be an anime that would scare away beginners with its fast pacing, tons of dialogue and weirdness. Tatami Galaxy is not an anime I can easily describe for a spoiler-free review. Trust me in that this show is truly a good one. The score on MAL does not lie this time, it's even not high enough. I know this is a bit of a half-assed review but this is the best that I can do right now. 


Tatami Galaxy is great. 


And with that, see you in my next review.

"being different and being good are not the same thing". me.
I usually watch anime by their rating, and I wasnt let down once. Until Tatami Galaxy. It's so horrifyingly horrendous that if I lose my concentration now I would not be able to finish the review. A mystery anime is good when it tries to make you brainstorm about the story/plot, not wasting time figuring out what is the content of the narration with full of redundant, complex, lengthy sentences speaking at 2x speed. Even reading sub didnt help much 
Story. 1/10
the whole plot of the anime can be explained in 2 minute scene withFortune Teller saying whatever it is about no matter what you choose it would be the same if you dont pick the right choice, and instead they tried to drag it into 11 eps with so much repetitions. Watching this anime be like walking into a maze, and then after 6 hours, you come out getting nothing but a pat on the head from the adult saying "good job performing a difficult task. you get nothing son". And then you feel like a super hero for being able to suffer such a challenge, and brag about it but in the end of the day you will never ever do it again. But me, I started walking halfway into the maze, and then I realized what was waiting for me at the end, and then I teleport out and say "no thank you i dont need this crap".


Art. 3/10.


If story is an edgy kid trying to be different, then why not the art? Sure lets join the edgy circle. But I'll mince my words and put it simple. Art is different, but it doesnt click me. move on


Sound. 5/10


Finishing the anime for half an hour (dropping to be precise), and all I could recall is the part when Seitarou sang at the river. And since I dont remember the sound at all considering I just watch it half an hour, it will fit the group "bland and forgettable at most". And ED may scare people with trypophobia. 


Character. 3/10

What's an anime without characters? more like What's an edgy anime without edgy characters? The only acceptable, sane character in this anime is Akashi. The rest are so inhuman, unreal that sometimes i think they are just a bunch of ideas being humanized and put into the anime to make it more edgy (spoil me if it is actually correct)


Enjoyment. 1/10

The plot is not even new, the narrative is way too fast with redundantly lengthy sentences, art is indifferent at most, sound is forgettable. 9/10 of the anime is filled with nonsense, so i would give it a solid 1/10


Overall. 1/10 but if only i was an elitist who like to ask my friend hey have you watch this anime or that anime while naming a bunch of hardcore stuffs, and posted on different social networks "Your name is overrated trash" then I would give it 10/10.

Best of the best. Makes you believe in animation as the best medium for storytelling. Makes you laugh and feel pits of despair simultaneously. Makes you intimately familiar with a cast of characters, so eccentric and wacky and yet so developed you could guess their favorite flavor of ice cream.
I was already deeply in love with Masaaki Yuasa and Tomihiko Morimi's other collaboration, "Night is Short, Walk on Girl", which in the past year has catapulted itself into becoming one of my all-time favorite films. Tatami Galaxy (or 4.5 Tatami Mythological Chronicles) is not quite as magnificent as that movie, but it's pretty darn close.This thing's as close to perfection as a TV anime is going to get, I imagine.


The entire thing follows this formula of a self-defeating, cynical college student going through alternate timelines, picking different clubs and trying to achieve great success, but continuously failing. Through this you get to see a dozen different angles of the same cast, meeting and interacting and falling into the same storylines. Like any formula-based series, though, the anime is best when it suddenly diverges from the expected and goes its own way, subverting the formulas to show you something new that you hadn't considered. When Tatami Galaxy does this, it does it with a narrative skill I don't think I've ever seen in another story before. Like, geez.


This is the only TV show I have ever watched in one sitting; I just never have the patience to sit through a bunch of episodes in a row... except for with Tatami Galaxy. Holy crap is this show good.

Great story that had very practical lessons and remarkable broadness of themes, with very legitimate relatability, a trait rare in many anime. 
The avant garde, highly stylized aesthetic I feel in some ways detracted from the execution of the overall story and is in other ways I must grant, lost on me. While watching, it was my biggest issue cause I can fully believe that the story itself was a masterpiece in its design, where it was a deeply relatable story with memorable characters that brought an almost unparalleled sense of reality to the table, an exceedingly rare feat.  
However, outside of even thevisual appearance, Tatami also drug its feet in full development of characters and the plot, and at times left me wishing it could have been improved and in some points even reworked entirely- especially in terms of pacing. But in the ending, I felt as if the climax and conclusion was rushed. Overall I give the Tatami Galaxy an 7/10, all the while I admit, wistfully wishing it was better; because, the story has such an enormous potential that ended up through a few flaws, short of its full fruition.

There are many reviews out there for this anime already, so why write another one?
Well, because it deserves it.
Not only that, but this won't be one of those ''structured'' reviews where I give scores to Sound/Art etc, rather, I'll just try to be ''different'' (as this show is) and talk about it in a way that would be more appealing and natural, as if I were an actual friend of yours telling you bits and pieces of it so that I can convince you that this really is worth your time.
I apologize if I'm not able to convey much though, as this is only mysecond review and I'm still not used to it. I may also commit some grammar mistakes, as English isn't my native language.


Tatami Galaxy was an anime I decided to watch on a whim, I didn't care much for it after reading its description, thinking it wouldn't be all that interesting... Well, I have to say it was one of the best decisions I have made.


The very first episode had me hooked. Now, before I go any deeper, I must say -


Do not judge this anime based on its Art (that is, if it doesn't suit you the very first time you look at it). The art is quite different and the characters rather exquisite, but this has a purpose, it fits the theme beautifully, and in fact, after 1 or 2 episodes you understand why it looks the way it does and it grows on you.


Tatami Galaxy shows us something many of us have thought about before:


What would I do if I had the chance to go back in time and do things differently? How would I change my path? What could I improve? Would I have the guts to ask that girl out?


Obviously, this isn't the first time a form of media deals with this issue, however, the difference here is how they present it, which is magnificent.


You'll just have to trust me on this one and watch it for yourself because no amount of words will do justice to it.


I know I said I would not give separate scores here, but I must point out that the sound in this anime is really great.


If you're tired of formulaic/generic/typical anime or just want to try something new, this is the one to shoot for. You won't be disappointed.

I absolutely love the Mind Game movie so when i heard this series was also done by Masaaki Yuasa i was extremely excited to check this out...all-in-all it was quite enjoyable
Storyline
The overall plot is pretty straightforward in hindsight but starts out somewhat confusing
Each episode canters around our main character Watashi, a university student who is always agonising about how he has wasted the last couple years of his college life on his already chosen club activity.
Looking back on his entrance to university, Watashi declares he could have achieved the rosey coloured college experience full of love, happiness and pure fulfilment that many other people seemto be having all around him……if only he had made a different choice back at the beginning of college maybe he coulda had that rosey coloured experience….….if only……………if only


Well, unbeknownst to Watashi some unknown force grants him his desire as at the end of every episode time is reversed and Watashi relives the start of his college life where he proceeds to take a different club activity from the previous one which results in a completely different college experience for our awkward protagonist


Alas, whether he joins the film club, tennis club or even the cycling club we soon see that through the following years Watashi’s choices end up leaving him gloriously unfulfilled and utterly disappointed…..and we the viewer’s get to watch the hilarious cycle replay itself out again and again in many different yet interesting scenarios.


Throughout Watashi’s college misadventures we will meet a slew of interesting characters, witness the highs and lows of his strange college life and ultimately be faced with the overwhelmingly elusive question Watashi cannot seem to find an answer to


Where can he find his true happiness in his tatami shaped world?


Animation


Madhouse...wow…you outdid yourself with this one


The animation uses a combination of simplicity in terms of character design and meshes it with vibrant and dazzling colours and shapes which give the animation a particularly likeable charm.


As the series goes on the animation also begins to meld with real images and even some obscured 3D imagery to bring a kind of trippy experience that reminds me more of the style Studio 4oC uses.


Overall, the weird and unique animation style is just the perfect fit for this offbeat comedy / drama and I personally found it to be a creative breath of fresh air in the midst of what I usually see in your typical anime series. I luuuved it!


Sound


Firstly, the Music is great. Opening theme is pretty charming and upbeat…and the closing theme is just fucking beautiful to listen to and really fits the mood of the show.


Now…an issue many people have with this show is the dialogue ….it can be fast…extremely fast in fact..which to non-Japanese speaking viewers can be a huge turn off as our main character Watashi goes into motor mouth monologues in almost every episode which results in HYPER FAST English subtitles that require pausing at times. This was admittedly a minor issue for me as well since Watashi spouts a lot of witty and comical information very fast….but to be honest I could see it was part of his charm and awkward personality to talk that way and eventually I found I got used to it.


Other than that I really enjoyed the other voice actors and I would ABOSOLUTELY LOVE an English dub of this show…which should have already happened since Funimation have already licensed this series but just have not dubbed it yet for some odd reason….a serious wtf there tbh.


Characters


Characters in this show are very likeable and three dimensional. As the series progresses you get to understand more and more about the supporting characters and as such they grow on you more and more and I certainly appreciated that.


Watashi himself…is kind of the loveable nerd dumbass


He is that kind of Woody Allen type that is smart in some ways but is utterly naive and pessimistic in others which does make the show that much more comical but can be irritating in some other situations he gets himself into.


By the end of the series you will come to realise most of the characters do not tend to be the predictable archetypes they seemed to be in the beginning and I found that to be an extremely pleasant surprise.


And on a side note it was bloodly hilarious to see Watashi constantly arguing with his mental “Johnny” who looks creepily similar to a particularly well known Walt Disney character lol


Enjoyment


Once again the overwhelming hype of this show is what initially drew me towards it and I have to admit at first it was a little bit of a chore to watch as things were a bit all over the place at the start but as time went on and I started to watch the series more slowly…even re-watching one or two episodes…it really grew on me and I can see why many people are drawn to this off beat and uniquely animated time twisted comedy drama.


Value


Value for this show is very high for me. I would love to watch this again in a good English dub and pick up each and every joke while enjoying the crazy animation style because tbh I let a couple of things go over my head as this show does move quite fast in terms of dialogue.


It’s nice to see something totally different in anime every once in a while and this show is not that long (11 episodes) so I’d say check it out, however i would be lying if I said I’d thought this show is for everyone…it’s too offbeat for me to say it has a broad appeal that almost anyone could enjoy


I think if you watch 3 episodes you’ll know if you’d like it or not….for me I’d say it was pretty good in Japanese but would be even better with an English dub….a quality English dub…by the guys who already have the US distribution rights


Make it happen Funimation….Make it happen damn you!


Planet Tyro Rating: Solid B


Visual Version: http://bit.ly/19h1xFr


planettyro.com

The Tatami Galaxy is a unique series that pushes the boundaries of conventional anime. It's a coming-of-age story of a young adult that involves time travel, discovering one's self, appreciation of what you have, and more.
Story: 9/10
Tatami Galaxy manages to flesh out a fantastic story in merely 11 episodes. It doesn't feel too short nor does it feel too long. It wraps the story up so that it doesn't leave you feeling awkward. I would have given it a 10/10, had it not been for the fact that, at times, it does seem repetitive. But then again, such is the nature of the story dueto the way it employs time travel. I also marathoned it, so that is another reason why. 


Art: 10/10

The artistic style is by far the show's strongest point. The show uses a minimalist style that doesn't come off as amateur, weak, or "we're low on budget so just get the damn thing done." It's a breath of fresh air compared to conventional anime. Additionally, it employs real life stills/video and seamlessly incorporates it into the anime. It would seem that the use of monochromatic colors would hurt the show, but it instead adds to its strength by giving flavor to each episode. 


Sound: 10/10

Great music and great soundtrack. Although most of the songs are great as in "it's great in a film, but I wouldn't listen to it without the film" there are quite a few tracks that can stand alone. The opening song (and sequence) really captures the essence of the show. It should be noted that the opening song was by Asian Kung-Fu Generation. The ending song was good as well, but it didn't captivate me as much as the opening song did. 


Characters: 9/10

This would have been a 10/10 were it not for a few hiccups. There were a couple of characters that were not fleshed out enough, and some of the characters can even be interpreted as a mirrors for the different aspects of the main character's personality, but I think this has to do with the nature of the story itself, as well as an unreliable narrator. 


Enjoyment: 10/10

I thoroughly enjoyed Tatami Galaxy, and I plan on re-watching it again so that I can better appreciate it. 


Overall: 9/10

The score speaks for itself. One concern I had was the lack of dubs. While I usually watch subs, this is one show that really needs a dub due to the fast pace dialogue. It can be quite difficult to keep up with the conversations and monologues. Honestly, there were times where I had to pause to read the text. The biggest drawback is that because you have to spend an above average amount of focus and energy on reading the subs, you thus fail to give the animation its appropriate attention. Nonetheless, you do eventually adapt to its pace, and it does get easier to watch as you move on.

Tatami Galaxy was genius. It's rare to find an anime that is as unique, thought-provoking, artful, clever, painfully real and beautiful at the same time. It left a lasting impression on me and will not be forgotten for a long time.
But I don't think this show is for everybody. The concepts are pretty hard to grasp, and I can understand how someone could become confused, scared or angry after watching. I don't think it's a matter of intelligence, but rather of the viewer's psychological state. I personally felt a connection to it as a 20 year old entering my third year of engineering school, andfelt like I shared a lot of similar thoughts with the main character. I would highly recommend this to the salty singles who thrive in the darkness and enjoy being alone, or somebody who's bored and looking for something unique.


Story 10/10

At first I was a little confused by the plot line, but after finishing the final episode it all made sense. The first two episodes actually left me really depressed. I believe the synopsis described the plot as a kind of supernatural journey, but I don't think that's really correct; it's something a little more intricate than your typical time-travelling show. I'll leave it up to you to decide after watching it yourself because that's not the purpose of this review. The plot is very detailed and you will be left with questions that are answered in following episodes, so don't give up when you're feeling confused. It's pretty outstanding how well they integrated every detail and definitely deserves my 10.


Art 10/10

The art is definitely a notable point of this anime. It's unique from any other anime I've seen and because of it, carves its own place in my mind. Though it doesn't really contribute to the quality of the art, I was kind of relieved that the characters actually had squinty eyes. Not a point of criticism, but I feel that in too many shows the characters have eyes that are so big they make my own eyes water, and don't even remotely look like their ethnicity. I still enjoy the art of large eyed anime's a lot, but I just noticed Tamami Galaxy's squinty eyes. Putting that aside, I hope you will appreciate the quality of Galaxy's unique artwork yourself.


Sound 10/10

I'm including voice acting as part of the sound. The main character's voice actor was amazing. I don't understand Japanese and the main character had blazing fast soliloquies, but you could still make out every syllable (not that I understood, but it was pretty amazing to listen to). The music did a pretty good job adding drama to the show as well, but I think it was mainly the main character's voice acting that drives my rating up to a 10.


Character 10/10

I really liked how the characters were developed in this anime. All the characters are seen from the perspective of the unnamed protagonist (I believe he was called 'Watashi' in the character list, but if I'm not mistaken that just means 'me'), and each time they appear you will discover a bit more about their intentions, methods and even appearance through their speech and their actions. The main exhibit of the series was the progress of the protagonist's views on the world as he traverses the Tatami Galaxy. I won't discuss that because its meaning is quite open to interpretation. Anyways, if you enjoy anime that is centered around character development, you might be interested to watch this show.


Enjoyment 10/10

I think that it was kind of a difficult watch for most of the season, maybe because of the page long subtitles that flashed on the screen every couple seconds. It's also pretty hard to grasp what's going on for the majority of the show, which is why I can understand why people wouldn't like it and would be turned away without finishing it. Personally, watching the first two episodes left me quite depressed, but not sad. Well, my point is that it was very relatable for me and I found an inexplicable motivation to finish watching the series without any rational reason. I found the ending to be very satisfying and well thought out, and I only found that I enjoyed it after I'd finished watching it, so don't give up!

I loved Akashi. The things she said to the protagonist were so subtle but at the same time so perfect that it I found myself giggling like a little girl. 


Overall 10/10

The genius plot, rapid-fire voice acting, beautiful art and relatable characters were all excellent. The quality in which it was all produced was excellent. The design was excellent. It was all so original that I wouldn't really  compare it to anything I've seen before. Absolutely mind-blowing whenever I think about it. 

I personally found that Tatami Galaxy was really amazing, but again, I can understand why people may be dissuaded from finishing the series or miss out in enjoying it. Regardless, I will still recommend it 9001% to anyone who's looking for an anime that's unique.

I get what the message is here. I really do. In fact, I'm the guy who SHOULD be getting the most out of this series, considering I'm around the same age as the protagonist and have many similar experiences. But I felt like the message just fell flat, for various reasons.
The anime "The Tatami Galaxy" is an episodic anime, so the episodes, for the most part, don't relate to each other (aside from the fact that the protagonist is going back in time to relive a part of his life a different way each episode). Seeing the different ways the protagonist lived his life aswell as the various running gags playing out differently each time was entertaining.


However, as I'm giving this series a 6/10, there are a few problems. First off, at LEAST one of the episodes was honestly just too weird for me. And this is coming from a guy who has watched a LOT of anime. I couldn't relate to the events happening and I couldn't tell if they were supposed to be played straight or played for comedy.


Second, and more importantly, I could tell that the series was building up to some sort of grand conclusion that tied everything together. The protagonist was going to find love, pick the right girl, etc. That's what was hinted at the whole time. But then the series wove another message into the story, and the big reveal of that came two episodes BEFORE the final episode. This left the final two episodes to have another random rewind, and those two episodes were honestly just tedious and boring.


Then the "real" ending. The real ending, in my opinion, was bad. First off, the protagonist realizes something about another main character that, honestly, I did not believe. The series did not do a good enough job convincing me of that point, so it fell horribly flat. Then, they finally get to that big "do the right thing" moment, and...they blow it off. The "resolution" happens in 3 seconds and then they LAUGH about not showing more of it. Yes, in the actual show.


So basically, for me, everything the show built up to fell flat. I'm the kind of guy that needs a good ending to tie a story together. If the ending doesn't satisfy me, ultimately it leaves the whole show in a bad light. If you can appreciate the journey a bit more than I do, or if you can except the premise they introduce at the end, you might really enjoy this series. I, on the other hand, found it only average.

MILD SPOILERS AHEAD
The Tatami Galaxy is about a university student who is stuck in a time loop, and when he is dissatisfied with the current time loop he goes back in time to a point which the protagonist(Watashi) specifies at the end of each episode(unaware of the time loop), each time joining a different 'circle' in search of a 'rose coloured life'. 
This anime utilises the time loop in a very clever way, by having each episode focus on a different circle and at the end having the time loop occur so the next episode will have a different circle, which makes this anime episodic,however some of the circumstances that may have occurred in each episode will still be in the following episodes albeit slightly changed because Watashi himself has changed his life by going back in time and joining different circles. 


At the first 9 episodes it has this episodic theme to it, which and it may sound repetitive, but its not, each episode may have similar themes to it but the actual content to each and Watashi's perspectives is completely different which makes it quite entertaining. This all builds up to create the best conclusion i have ever seen in the last two episodes, which plays with all of the previous themes but there is one major difference and this difference cause the time loops to stop. This conclusion tells the viewer a powerful message of living life to its fullest, and one could find many more messages that this show is telling the reader. The Tatami Galaxy completely disregards most anime tropes and creates such a fresh and original experience that it felt like watching anime for the first time, the originality in this show however may not be up to everyone as the way it's narrated and the way the plot is presented is such an alien experience to the causal anime fan, however for those who are not put off by it, watch it, you'll will love the conclusion and everything about it. 


The art is very cartoonish and fluid so this also may not be for the most people as the art style's originality may be discredited as it is so different from all of the other generic anime art style's, which truly makes this anime one of a kind. But if you are fine with the art style, than this will be an enjoyable watch for you as the art style really helps to bring about this anime's originality and beauty. The sound for this anime is quite stellar, the opening is very catchy and is accompanied by a amazing visuals, the ending is also accompanied by great visuals but the vocals in it are very good. The OST through The Tatami Galaxy is incredible as well and it emphasises the most important and memorable moments.


The characters of The Tatami Galaxy aren't really the focus point of it but each character is unique in their own way, this really adds to the originality of the show, and in each different circle their actions and Watashi's perceptions of them may change but the message they are portraying don't change. Each character sticks out in their own way and this makes the show more memorable for the viewer, and at the conclusion each characters is involved, they each have a part to play to emphasise their own specific messages.


This is one of those anime, that doesn't need stunningly animated fight scenes or the breathtaking visuals to stand put but instead an intelligible audience which can truly appreciate it for all of its wacky weirdness and beautiful storytelling. I would recommend anyone to watch it as it is a very original experience as it stands out from the classic norm in terms of art style, and the way the plot is presented.

' Life is not meant to be sought or measured, life is meant to be lived.'
An anime that holds no need for superficial or amazing concepts to be successful, it's  just a realistic story executed in a masterful way...ladies and gentlemen i present you = Tatami Galaxy
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Story : 10/10 - Outstanding
Tatami Galaxy is set in Kyoto if i'm not mistaken, well it's not that important ,it's just one of those Japanese towns. Our MC, 'Watashi', a freshman engineering student,  expects to find the 'rose colored campus life' that he always dreamed of, entering a campus club (circle) to meet 'the raven-haired girl ofhis dreams'. After joining a club in his first year,he meets Ozu, another freshman student in his department who has a very misfit persona. 2 years pass and at the same time he contemplates his affection for  another engineering student, Akashi, and makes promises to her, usually of and within a romantic subtext. Now In his 3rd year, instead of reaching his "rose colored campus life dream" he finds mischief and disappointment, he also doesn't find a chance to ask out Akashi, long story short: everything goes wrong as he ends up regretting his club choice, wanting to go back to the moment of choosing it resets his life and  he changes his choice.  BUT, as  he joins a different club, everything seem to go wrong again despite changing his choice and again he ends up regretting his choice and resets again. This goes on and on as he always ends up regreting his choice and resets , also his dubious missions often conflict with his interest in Akashi in some way as he always ends up not having a chance to ask her out. The plot is following his different choices and the different lives he lived after them. 


Basically, this formula of "resetting" continues on until the last two episodes but eventually it leads to one of most satisfying conclusions you can ever see in an anime.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Art: 9/10 - Great


'It's  inventive and distinctive and regularly beautiful'. 


Seen as poor by many, the art of Tatami Galaxy is gravely underrated but the funny thing is that Tatami Galaxy won the grand prize for the animation category in the Japan Media Arts Festival on December 8, 2010. It was the first time a TV animation series won the grand prize.


Art effectively depicts the themes of the show, It will regularly spin through a dozen visual styles in a single minute, combines gloriously abstract representations and actual live footage sometimes, illustrates its protagonists’ barreling inner monologue through an endless buffet of visual metaphors. And all that visual stuff doesn’t exist in a vacuum, either - it is an integral part of the storytelling, and the two compliment each other perfectly.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Sound: 10/10 - Outstanding


A testament to the superb voice acting could be that, even though 'Watashi's speech is faster than a bullet train, he still manages to keep the viewer in his toes with his smart (and funny) take on many different subjects and make him feel whatever emotion he emits. Akashi's and Ozu's voice are on spot too.


As for the soundtrack, it fits great with the theme and mood of the series, successfully representing the constant changes in atmosphere, from the melancholic "Youjou han to Castella to Watashi" to the mysterious "Kamotaketsunuminogami" and powerfully liberating "Yojouhan Ki Owari" or "Takasegawa" and of course, hands down to OP:  "Maigoinu to Ame no Beat" by Asian Kung-Fu Generation completely catches the theme of the show and captures you with it's beat, you can't help but to sing along. ED theme is "Kami-sama no Iutōri ("As God Dictates") has a completely different air to it that captures you, oh and after the end of 10th episode , you will look to ED in a different way , i assure you.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Characters: 10/10 - Outstanding


Cast is the recipe for instant success. You will immediately fell in love with them.

I will briefly describe the 3 main characters and  one of the supporting characters.


1) MC : 'Watashi' is a young college student in the engineering department who never seizes to amaze with his sarcastic and dark but witty dialogues on everything he analyzes. He is the source of the dialogues and monologues in Tatami Galaxy, and his themes vary from social commentary to self - sarcasm of the highest caliber. He entered college dreaming of the "rosy campus life"  and wanting to meet the 'raven-haired girl of his dreams', which is why he joins a new social circle/club in each episode. 


2) Ozu is another college student in the engineering department. Misfit, dark and devilish character, who constantly drags 'Watashi' to troubles. He's often the one manipulating the other characters against the protagonist. He also seems to care for the protagonist, and rescues him on certain occasions from sticky situations, they have a complicated relationship, as series progress it becomes more clear. 


3) Akashi, is another college student in the engineering department , is an adorable female character, and 'Watashi's biggest love interest. She is commonly the center of the protagonist's affections, she acts rationally and even coldly towards most people, but often shows hints of affection to the protagonist. Her fear of moths also contrasts with her normally calm demeanor. She often appears in the same club that the protagonist joins, though her main club is 'Birdman circle', some sort of engineering circle that designs Light Sport Aircrafts.


Higuchi is a stoic, and full with dreams on exploring the globe, he 's originally introduced as a deity of matrimony (god of marriage) in the first episode, but he is depicted in the rest of the series as an eighth year student living in the same dorm as the protagonist. He also has many hidden sides, which made him mysterious, spiritual and occasionally wise.

There are more supporting characters that are also very interesting like another eight year student, Masaki Jōgasaki, but doesn't quite measure up to the other mentioned above. However, there is not a single character that is not likable in this series, because of their quirks and personality.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Enjoyment: 10/10 - Outstanding


Fully enjoyed of every minute of the show, especially the last episode.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Overall: 10/10 - Outstanding + Masterpiece 


Masterpiece is pretty much the word when it comes to Tatami Galaxy - every element of its production glimmers with polish.



It's not everyone's cup of tea and some even call it '2deep4u' despite it's simple messages , for example:


*Do not let your dreams like " I want a rose-colored life"  blind the already beautifully colored life you have been living all along , it does not have to be rose colored, it's beautifully colored as it is. Don't project your failures and personal ugliness outwards,  embraces all the cracks and imperfections that made your life worth living, take responsibility for your own journey.


*Do not let your dreams like  " I want to be with raven haired girl of my ideals"  blind you, just seize the opportunity in front of you and open up to girl you want to open up to, yes, that adorable girl right in front of you : that girl who liked your silly movies, that girl who enjoyed your silly performances, that girl who wanted to visit your favorite ramen shop with you,


' Life is not meant to be sought or measured, life is meant to be lived.'

This show’s answer to the question of the meaning of life seems to be “drink your tea.”  To put it briefly :  Show is telling you ' just live to YOUR fullest ', 



For me this is one of the greatest series I've ever seen, The Tatami Galaxy deserves  an EXTREMELY OBVIOUS 10/10 from the overall score.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


LAST WORDS: People don't call this show masterpiece for no reason, it's truly a hidden gem,  This may be the best show you haven't watched, i can't say enough about how good the show is. It's whimsical, funny, yet deep, sending a good and yet a simple message to us all. The characters seem pretty 'normal' at first, but at the end, you can't help but to love every single one of them. It's a very experimental, yet cleverly put together show. Minute for minute this was one of the most worthwhile watching experiences I've ever had, anime or not.  Overall an extremely charming and colorful  piece of work, one that I'll NEVER forget.


Honestly you have to watch it to understand it but after you watch it,  it WILL to be in your top 10 , maybe 5.


So yeah, that’s The Tatami Galaxy,  a perfect little tatami box of its own. 


Thank you for reading.

This hidden gem sure deserves a perfect 10 from me.
--------------CONTAINS MINOR SPOILERS------------------------------------------------------------------
 Summary-Watashi is like the adult version of nobita, except way better and funnier too. All he wants an enjoyable college life ,he desperately repeats the first 2 years of his college life going back and forth into the past  to change his decisions to make his 2 years of high school life rememberable , searching for the "rose-colored campus life", and the "raven-haired maiden" that supposedly awaits him. The last 2 episodes of the anime is where I realized this anime is a true gem. After the first episode, I was deeplyinvolved into the story as it somewhat similar to my highschool days (sad, I couldn't change my decisions though).



~At first glance, I was really worried, whether the anime will live upto my expectations as its only 11 episodes long. So, the plot might be fastforward towards the end but, fortunately I was wrong. After watching this original anime masterpiece, I realized I shouldn't judge an anime based on its episode count.


Genres-Mystery, Romance, Psychological,Comedy (I wonder why MAL didn't put comedy tag in it, it was quite funny at times)


Story-10/10 (Every episode is different and tells us from a unique point of view,but gradually you wiill start noticing the pattern that's the best part about this series)

Enjoyment-over 9000 (Definitely has high rewatch value for me)

Bizarre, confusing, and yet mind-warpingly brilliant – what was initially an Asanuma Shintarou fact-finding mission on my part turned into a very trippy and fulfilling mind trip into the world of The (4.5) Tatami Galaxy.
Story.
We kick start things with paragraphs on end of extremely quick narration from our protagonist, Watashi, who recounts his life as a fresh university student with hopes of achieving his desired ‘rose-coloured campus life’. Which circle does he choose? Where does he end up? Would he be happy in the tennis circle, the softball circle, the drama circle or the cycling circle? Would he be happy if he chose to meethis pen pal, to be with a life-sized doll or to go drinking with a friend of his? There are so many possibilities, permutations and combinations, that it is just so difficult to decide! However, this series does not leave viewers to speculate, because in what is a most fascinating take on repeated ‘what if’s, Yojouhan Shinwa Taikei gives us a full blown account of how Watashi’s life for the next couple of years would pan out depending on which circle he chose at the start of his university life. And that is the point at which the hands on the clock start spiralling out of control, because each episode after depicts Watashi’s life, but that in a different club. It is as if we hit the ‘reset’ button at the end of each episode and Watashi gets a retake on the past two years of his life. One would think that's a convenient setting – Don't like it? Then just redo it. But at what point do we keep turning back time? How many times do we repeat life until we are satisfied with its outcome? That really, is what I believe to be Yojouhan's overarching theme, and it was one that the series not only addressed, but explored very thoroughly and very satisfyingly.


With Yojouhan Shinwa Taikei, perseverance is key because three episodes in and it seems as if the story is still going pretty much nowhere. Add to that the episodic first-person narrative of the series, and what we get is a recount (on steroids) of the protagonist’s life set on loop. It doesn’t exactly sound that appealing, but just trust me on this, stick to it all the way to the end and what you will get is a really satisfying ending. Because while the episodic and repetitive nature of the series serves to confuse, it is this very style of narrative that definitely helps put Watashi’s perspective across clearly. With each repetition, we get yet another piece of the tatami puzzle; with each repetition, we get more insight into all the different worlds that Watashi has lived in; with each repetition, this series manages to drive its point across even more clearly than before. And what's really impressive is how the series managed to weave the storyline from each parallel world so seamlessly. We had references here and there with the castella, the neko ramen and the proxy wars, to name a few, but none of them were at all out of place or mentioned in vain.


Just what I love about this series is how thought provoking it turned out to be (at least, that is my take on it. What can I say? I like to think... lol). We saw the extent to which Watashi’s life would be different depending on the choices he made – indeed, one’s fate could change from the tiniest of choices. Watashi’s ups and downs were central in showing us that, from him wanting that ‘rose-coloured campus life’, to him cooping himself up in his room (to that I say, viva hikkikomori lifestyle!), and finally to him agonising about being trapped in his tatami hell and fervently wishing that he had done ALL that he had done in the previous episodes upon traversing all the different parallel worlds. That really laid on the ‘what if’s oh so heavily and gets one thinking twice / thrice / many times over just what decision would be the would be the "best" decision.


And I pause at the mention of the "best" decision. Because what really is the "best" decision? Looking back on the episodes, viewers went on the journey with Watashi as he experienced life in the various circles, and not one of them stood out as being the "best" outcome to me. Which then begs the question as to whether there really is such a thing as a 'rose-coloured campus life'. What is a 'rose-coloured campus life' in the first place? It was obviously a term that Watashi coined, and he was so caught up in the pursuit of his ideal, that he lost sight of what happiness stood right before his very eyes. And that was what really got to me, because I do think that we are often so overwhelmed in the pursuit of our notion of ideal that we do not live in the 'now'. My takeaway from Yojouhan: hold back on the obsessing; stop and smell the roses once in awhile.



Characters.


Yojouhan has a series of very colourful characters, each playing a pivotal role in the story. There’s our protagonist, whom we know only as Watashi, who takes us through his many parallel lives. Then there is his friend from the dark side of the moon, Ozu – Watashi's first encounter with his worst encounter. According to Watashi, 8 out of 10 people would believe Ozu to be a youkai if they saw him in the dark, while the remaining 2 could be convinced of it. He serves as the troublemaker in this series, eating the unhappiness of others as a topping on his rice, as Watashi so delicately puts it. And while Watashi is convinced that his soul would have stayed unblemished had he not met Ozu, he just can’t seem to shake him off because the two are connected by the so-called black string of fate. We also have the level-headed Akashi, whom Watashi finally reaches out to, Jougasaki who is just sooo weird (seriously, a love doll? *shudder*), the senpai figure Higuchi and even a vague fortune teller whose fees just keep increasing lol (but I guess if her advice is legit, then why not?). These characters really do get up to some of the most amusing antics and there is never a dull moment watching their interactions. While comedy isn't the main aspect of this series, Yojouhan was still spot on with its humour and managed to incite a good number of laughs.



Art.


Produced in traditional animation by Madhouse under the direction of Masaaki Yuasa, this series is based on a novel written by Tomihiko Morimi. Story aside, the animation was different from most of the anime I have seen, but it took no time at all for me to get used to.
